column6: definition
column7: example_usage

column6: Measures blood level of digoxin heart medicine.
column7: Digoxin level is 1.2 ng/mL in therapeutic range.

column6: Measures blood level of vancomycin antibiotic.
column7: Vancomycin trough is 18 mcg/mL.

column6: Measures blood level of anti-seizure medicine phenytoin.
column7: Phenytoin level too low at 6 mcg/mL.

column6: Measures blood level of theophylline asthma medicine.
column7: Theophylline level is 12 mcg/mL within range.

column6: A screening test for human immunodeficiency virus.
column7: Fourth generation HIV test is best.

column6: Tests for hepatitis A B and C viruses.
column7: Hepatitis panel ordered for yellow skin patient.

column6: A marker of active hepatitis B infection.
column7: Positive HBsAg means current HBV infection.

column6: Shows immunity to hepatitis B from vaccine or past infection.
column7: Positive anti-HBs shows HBV immunity.

column6: Screening test for hepatitis C virus.
column7: Positive HCV antibody needs RNA test to confirm.

column6: A screening test for syphilis.
column7: Positive RPR confirmed with FTA-ABS.

column6: A computer check that shows if a patient's insurance is active and what it covers.
column7: Front desk staff run RTE before scheduling.

column6: A set amount of money a patient pays when they visit the doctor.
column7: Patient paid a $20 co-pay at check-in.

column6: The amount a patient must pay before their insurance starts paying for care.
column7: The patient has a $1500 deductible to meet.

column6: The percentage of the bill a patient pays after meeting their deductible.
column7: Patient is responsible for 20% coinsurance.

column6: A paper or online statement showing what the insurance paid and what the patient owes.
column7: Review the EOB to understand the claim payment.

column6: The most money a patient pays in one year before insurance covers everything.
column7: Patient has reached their $5000 OOP maximum.

column6: Permission from insurance needed before getting certain tests or treatments.
column7: MRI requires prior auth before scheduling.

column6: A type of insurance plan where you can see any doctor but pay less for in-network doctors.
column7: Patient has a PPO plan and can self-refer.

column6: A type of insurance that requires you to use specific doctors and get referrals to see specialists.
column7: HMO patients need a referral to see specialists.

column6: An insurance plan that mixes HMO and PPO rules.
column7: POS plan requires PCP coordination but allows out-of-network.

column6: Government health insurance mainly for people 65 and older.
column7: Patient is eligible for Medicare Part B.

column6: Government health insurance for people with low income.
column7: Patient has Medicaid coverage for the visit.

column6: The monthly payment to keep an insurance plan active.
column7: Monthly premium is $450 for family coverage.

column6: Medical care and tests that an insurance plan will pay for.
column7: Annual physical is a covered service.

column6: Services or treatments that insurance will not pay for.
column7: Cosmetic procedures are plan exclusions.

column6: Doctors and hospitals that have an agreement with your insurance company.
column7: Using in-network providers saves money.

column6: Doctors and hospitals that do not have an agreement with your insurance company.
column7: Out-of-network services cost more for patients.

column6: The maximum amount insurance will pay for a service.
column7: The allowable amount for the visit was $150.

column6: A request sent to insurance asking them to pay for services.
column7: Submit the claim within 30 days of service.

column6: An insurance request that was rejected and will not be paid.
column7: The claim was denied due to missing information.

column6: A common condition where stomach acid flows back into the throat causing heartburn.
column7: Patient diagnosed with GERD needs PPI medication.

column6: A system that checks if a patient's insurance is active and what services are covered.
column7: Run TES check before scheduling the appointment.

column6: A description of when the patient's symptoms started and how they have changed.
column7: The HPI documents when pain started and how bad it is.

column6: A checklist asking about symptoms in different parts of the body.
column7: Complete ROS includes all 14 body systems.

column6: When a doctor checks the patient's body by looking listening and touching.
column7: PE showed normal heart and lung sounds.

column6: The name of the disease or condition the patient has.
column7: Primary Dx is type 2 diabetes.

column6: The medical care given to help the patient get better.
column7: Tx includes lifestyle changes and metformin.

column6: A single visit between a patient and their doctor.
column7: Document the encounter in the EHR.

column6: A group of visits for the same health problem.
column7: The pneumonia episode included 3 office visits.

column6: A way to write medical notes using four sections.
column7: Use SOAP format for progress notes.

column6: The main reason the patient came to see the doctor.
column7: CC is chest pain for 2 hours.

column6: A list of all health problems the patient has had before.
column7: PMH includes high blood pressure and GERD.

column6: A list of all surgeries the patient has had.
column7: PSH includes appendectomy in 2010.

column6: Information about diseases that run in the patient's family.
column7: FH significant for heart disease and diabetes.

column6: Information about the patient's lifestyle like smoking and drinking.
column7: SH reveals 20 pack-year smoking history.

column6: A list of things that cause bad reactions in the patient.
column7: Allergies include penicillin and shellfish.

column6: A current list of all medicines the patient is taking.
column7: Medication list updated at every visit.

column6: Basic body measurements like temperature and blood pressure.
column7: Vital signs stable and normal.

column6: A note written during follow-up visits showing how the patient is doing.
column7: Progress note shows improvement in symptoms.

column6: A report written when a patient leaves the hospital.
column7: Discharge summary sent to PCP.

column6: A complete first exam including patient history and physical check.
column7: Complete H&P documented on admission.

column6: The doctor's conclusion about what is wrong with the patient.
column7: Impression is acute bronchitis.

column6: The treatment plan and next steps for the patient.
column7: Plan of care includes antibiotics and recheck in 3 days.

column6: Instructions written by the doctor for medicines or tests.
column7: Orders include CBC and basic metabolic panel.

column6: A blood test that measures different parts of blood including red cells white cells and platelets.
column7: Order CBC to check for anemia.

column6: Counts the number of white blood cells that fight infection.
column7: High WBC suggests infection.

column6: Counts the number of red blood cells that carry oxygen.
column7: Low RBC means anemia.

column6: A protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen through the body.
column7: Hemoglobin is 10.2 showing anemia.

column6: Shows what percent of blood is made of red blood cells.
column7: Hematocrit of 32% is below normal.

column6: Counts the platelets that help blood clot.
column7: Low platelets increase bleeding risk.

column6: Measures the average size of red blood cells.
column7: High MCV may mean vitamin deficiency.

column6: Measures how much hemoglobin is in each red blood cell.
column7: MCH helps find the type of anemia.

column6: Measures how concentrated hemoglobin is in red blood cells.
column7: High MCHC seen in some blood disorders.

column6: Measures if red blood cells are different sizes.
column7: High RDW shows mixed types of anemia.

column6: Breaks down the different types of white blood cells.
column7: Differential shows high neutrophils.

column6: White blood cells that fight bacterial infections.
column7: High neutrophils mean bacterial infection.

column6: White blood cells that fight viruses and help immunity.
column7: High lymphocytes suggest viral infection.

column6: White blood cells that eat germs and dead cells.
column7: High monocytes in long-term inflammation.

column6: White blood cells involved in allergies and parasite infections.
column7: High eosinophils suggest allergies or parasites.

column6: White blood cells involved in allergic reactions.
column7: High basophils are rare.

column6: A blood test checking electrolytes kidney function and blood sugar.
column7: Order BMP to check kidney function.

column6: A salt in blood that helps balance fluids and nerves.
column7: Sodium level is 138 mEq/L.

column6: A mineral critical for heart and muscle function.
column7: Potassium is 4.2 mEq/L.

column6: A salt that helps maintain fluid balance in the body.
column7: Chloride level is normal at 102 mEq/L.

column6: Measures bicarbonate which shows acid-base balance.
column7: CO2 of 24 means normal balance.

column6: Measures waste filtered by kidneys to check kidney function.
column7: High BUN suggests kidney problems.

column6: A waste product used to check how well kidneys work.
column7: Creatinine of 1.8 means decreased kidney function.

column6: Measures the amount of sugar in the blood.
column7: Fasting glucose is 110 mg/dL.

column6: A bigger blood test that includes BMP plus liver and protein tests.
column7: Order CMP for complete health check.

column6: Measures all proteins in blood to check nutrition and liver health.
column7: Total protein helps check liver function.

column6: A protein made by the liver that keeps fluid balanced.
column7: Low albumin means malnutrition or liver disease.

column6: A liver enzyme that goes up when the liver is damaged.
column7: AST of 85 suggests liver inflammation.

column6: A liver enzyme that is very specific for liver damage.
column7: High ALT means liver injury.

column6: An enzyme in liver and bones that goes up with certain diseases.
column7: High ALP suggests blocked bile ducts.

column6: A yellow substance from broken down red blood cells.
column7: High bilirubin causes jaundice.

column6: Bilirubin that has been processed by the liver.
column7: High direct bilirubin in blocked bile ducts.

column6: Bilirubin that has not been processed by the liver yet.
column7: High indirect bilirubin in blood cell breakdown.

column6: A mineral important for bones nerves and muscles.
column7: Calcium level is 9.5 mg/dL.

column6: A blood test checking cholesterol and fats to assess heart risk.
column7: Fasting lipid panel shows high LDL.

column6: Measures all cholesterol in blood including good and bad types.
column7: Total cholesterol is 220 mg/dL.

column6: Good cholesterol that helps remove bad cholesterol from blood.
column7: HDL of 55 mg/dL is protective.

column6: Bad cholesterol that can clog arteries and cause heart disease.
column7: LDL of 150 mg/dL is above goal.

column6: A type of fat in blood that increases heart disease risk when high.
column7: Triglycerides are 180 mg/dL.

column6: A type of cholesterol that carries triglycerides in blood.
column7: VLDL is calculated from triglycerides.

column6: Shows average blood sugar over the past 2-3 months for diabetes.
column7: HbA1c of 7.2% means diabetes not well controlled.

column6: Tests that check how well the thyroid gland is working.
column7: Thyroid panel ordered to check for low thyroid.

column6: A hormone that controls the thyroid gland.
column7: High TSH means low thyroid function.

column6: Active thyroid hormone that controls metabolism.
column7: Free T3 helps check thyroid function.

column6: Main hormone made by the thyroid gland.
column7: Free T4 measures available hormone.

column6: Active thyroid hormone not bound to proteins.
column7: Free T3 is low in low thyroid.
